Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly
Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones
A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the metacarpal bones, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones
A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones
A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement
Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers
Malalignement of carpal bone angles either with respect to each other, to the corresponding metacarpals or with respect to the wrist (radius and ulna)
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four
Increased mobility of one ore more metacarpophalangeal joint
Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as
Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers
Metacarpal that becomes thinner toward the distal end
Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers)

concept.display: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the fingers
concept.definition: Short, hypoplastic middle phalanx of finger, affecting all fingers

concept.display: Expanded phalanges with widened medullary cavities

concept.definition: The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease)

concept.display: Shortening of all distal phalanges of the fingers
concept.definition: Hypoplasia of all of the distal phalanx of finger
Some or all of the metacarpal bones (i.e., metacarpal II to V) have a pointed proximal appearance
A type of digital ulcer that manifests as an open sore on the surface of the skin at the tip of a finger or toe
Increased length of the proximal phalanx of finger
Rounding and broadening of the tufts of the distal phalanges
Abnormally large size of the metaphyseal epiphyses
Fusion of the epiphysis and metaphysis of one or more phalanges prior to the normal age or stage of growth

concept.display: Shortening of all proximal phalanges of the fingers
concept.definition: Congenital hypoplasia of proximal phalanx of finger or all fingers

A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal
Increased side-to-side width of the metacarpal epiphyses

concept.display: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
concept.definition: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases
Increased length of multiple or a single phalanx of finger
Bending or curvature of a thumb towards the ulnar side (towards the ring finger)
The presence of a supernumerary finger (not a thumb) involving the third or fourth metacarpal with associated osseous syndactyly
Irregular morphology of one or more metacarpal bones

concept.display: Short metacarpals with rounded proximal ends
Soft tissue swelling of interphalangeal joints

concept.definition: A morphological abnormality of distal phalanges such that they have the appearance of chess pawns

concept.display: Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones

concept.definition: Increase in bone density in the diaphyseal (shaft) region of a metacarpal bone

concept.display: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth

concept.definition: Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases
Excessively deep creases of the palm
Phalanges of the fingers becoming thinner toward the distal end
The middle phalanx of finger resembles a thimble, a small metal cap to protect the finger while sewing that has a broad (proximal) base and narrower top, whereby both base and top are flat

concept.display: Decreased movement range in interphalangeal joints

concept.definition: Alteration of the normally smooth radiographic contour of phalanges producing an irregular appearance

concept.display: Thin proximal phalanges with broad epiphyses of the hand
Single interphalangeal crease of fifth finger
concept.definition: Presence of only one (instead of two, as normal) interphalangeal crease of the fifth finger

concept.display: Limited mobility of proximal interphalangeal joint
Tapering pointed ends of distal finger phalanges
concept.definition: A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end such that the tip of the phalanx comes to a point (this feature can be observed on radiograms)

concept.display: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities
Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint

concept.definition: An increased resorption of bone matrix by osteoclasts leading to bony defects involving the tarsal bones
Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter)

concept.display: Shortening of all middle phalanges of the toes
concept.definition: Abnormal shortening of all middle phalanges of toes
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the wrist

The presence of discolored lateral incisors

concept.definition: An abnormality of tooth eruption
Agenesis of upper secondary incisor or of upper central primary incisor

Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention

A generalized form of microdontia
Increased space between the primary teeth. Note this phenotype should be distinguished from increased space due purely to microdontia
The presence of a single, median maxillary incisor, affecting both the primary maxillary incisor and the permanent maxillary incisor
Irregular distribution of the teeth along the dental arch, i.e., and irregular spatial pattern of teeth

An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta
An alteration of the normally relatively smooth margins of the kneecap in radiographic images leading to an irregular contour
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the distal epiphysis of the ulna

Progressive bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone

Shortening of the legs related to developmental hypoplasia of the bones of the leg
Underdevelopment of the distal epiphysis of the radius
Increased width of the distal part of the shaft (metaphysis) of the femur

Radial dysplasia, also known as radial longitudinal deficiency, includes radial clubhand and is a disfiguring, and potentially disabling, congenital limb anomaly. The entire upper limb may be involved, although the defect is most evident in the forearm and hand. Affected children suffer a variable degree of hypoplasia or absence of the preaxial skeleton and soft tissues, in particular the thumb, radius, and dorsoradial soft tissues. The hand is usually radially deviated and subluxated off the distal aspect of the ulna, the ulna may be shortened and have a bow-shaped deformity, and there is no true wrist (radiocarpal) joint in Bayne2 type-III and IV radial dysplasia
Proximal radial shortening owing to a congenital defect of development

concept.display: Disproportionate prominence of the femoral medial condyle
Enlargement of the distal femoral epiphysis
concept.definition: An abnormal enlargement of the distal epiphysis of the femur

concept.display: Increased density of long bone diaphyses

concept.definition: Underdevelopment or shortening of the end of the fibula (calf bone) nearest the knee
Absence of the patella

concept.display: Multicentric ossification of proximal femoral epiphyses
Lateral displacement of the femoral head
concept.definition: A developmental anomaly with lateral displacement of the femoral head
Formation of bone in the patella later than normal
Anomaly of the contour of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia such that its normally smooth appearance is irregular
Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is defined as a posterior and inferior slippage of the proximal epiphysis of the femur onto the metaphysis (femoral neck), occurring through the physeal plate during the early adolescent growth spurt
A generalized decrease in bone mineral density

concept.display: Periosteal thickening of long tubular bones
concept.definition: Thickening of the periosteum of long bone
A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle
A limitation of the range of movement of the shoulder joint
Decreased width of the diaphysis of long bones
An abnormal anterior curvature of a long bone

concept.display: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
concept.definition: An abnormality of the islet of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells. These are the alpha cells, which produce glucagon, the beta cells, which produce insulin and amylin, the delta cells, which produce somatostatin, the PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide, and the epsilon cells, which produce ghrelin
Any abnormality of the alveolar ridges (on the upper or lower jaws). The alveolar ridges contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth
An abnormality of the dental pulp
Premature loss of teeth not related to trauma or neglect
Any abnormality of the primary tooth
An abnormality of the morphology of the tooth
The presence of an altered number of of teeth
Agenesis of incisor
An abnormality of the dental root
A bending or abnormal curvature of a long bone
A bending or abnormal curvature affecting a long bone of the arm
An anomaly of the femoral metaphysis
Absence or underdevelopment of the fibula

concept.display: Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the lower limbs
concept.definition: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the bones of the lower limbs

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the feet

concept.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the ulna

concept.display: Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the upper limbs
concept.definition: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the bones of the upper limbs

concept.display: Abnormality of lower limb epiphysis morphology
concept.definition: An anomaly of one or more epiphyses of one or both legs
A small/hypoplastic or absent/aplastic radius
Absence or underdevelopment of the carpal bones

concept.display: obsolete Anomaly of the limb diaphyses morphology

concept.definition: An anomaly of one or more epiphyses of a limb
Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the humerus
An anomaly that is characterized progressive airflow obstruction that is only partly reversible, inflammation in the airways, and systemic effects or comorbities
An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat

Abnormal accumulation of surfactant-like, periodic acid-schiff-positive lipoproteinaceous material in macrophages within the alveolar spaces and distal bronchioles. This results in gas exchange impairment leading to dyspnea and alveolar infiltrates
Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition
Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus

Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid
A lymphocyte-predominant infiltration of the lungs characterized by bibasilar pulmonary infiltrates with dense interstitial accumulations of lymphocytes and plasma cells

According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities
An abnormality of the pulmonary lymphatic chain
Abnormality of the lung parenchyma extending to the pulmonary interstitium and leading to diffuse pulmonary fibrosis
An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia
A recurrent hemorrhage occurring within the lung
Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung
An increased susceptibility to bronchopulmonary infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchopulmonary infections

concept.display: obsolete Chronic obstructive airway disease from birth

concept.definition: A type of pulmonary sequestration that is completely enclosed in its own pleural sac, occurring above, within, or below the diaphragm, and without communication with the tracheobronchial tree

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins

Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver
A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis

concept.display: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
concept.definition: Decreased activity of complex III of the mitochondrion in the liver
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver
Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia
Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus

concept.display: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

concept.definition: Intermittently increased size of the liver
An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes
An increase in the amount of glycogen stored in hepatocytes compared to normal

concept.display: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
concept.definition: The presence of reduced numbers of intrahepatic bile duct than normal
An acute form of hepatic steatosis
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants
Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule

concept.display: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
concept.definition: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes
Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure

The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle
An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved
Prematurely closed sternal sutures
Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus
Bony fusion between the humerus and scapula, leading to an impairment in mobility of the affected shoulder joint
The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm

concept.display: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends

concept.definition: Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth border between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum
Early ossification of the costochondral junction, which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle
A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple

concept.display: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
concept.definition: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms
Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero
Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs
Abnormal increase in density of the tissue at the costochondral junctions
Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal
Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum
Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus
Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass)
Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle
More than one fracture of the ribs
Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles

Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax
Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions

concept.display: Thickening of the lateral border of the scapula

concept.definition: Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect
An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger)
Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec

Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells

Premature ventricular contractions (PVC) or ventricular extrasystoles are premature contractions of the heart that arise in response to an impulse in the ventricles rather than the normal impulse from the sinoatrial (SA) node
An abnormality of filling of a ventricle with blood during diastole

concept.display: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways
concept.definition: A form of ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of multiple accessory pathways for cardiac conduction
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium
Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta
A bacterial infection of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves
Calcium deposition in the myocardium

concept.display: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
concept.definition: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
Steatosis in the myocardium

concept.display: Early progressive calcific cardiac valvular disease

concept.definition: A defect of the atrioventricular septum of the heart
A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole
A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites
Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery
Any structural abnormality of the coronary arteries
An abnormality of an atrioventricular valve
An abnormality of the hepatic vasculature
Absence or underdevelopment of the clavicles (collar bones)

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the thorax

concept.definition: A form of acute leukemia characterized by excess lympoblasts
The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia of T-cell origin. It comprises about 15% of childhood cases and 25% of adult cases. It is more common in males than females
The presence of an follicular adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland
A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma in which the papillae are covered by large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and nuclear pseudostratification
A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts
The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney
Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia

concept.display: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
concept.definition: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium

concept.display: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
concept.definition: The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder with origin in a transitional epithelial cell
A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone
Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach
The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system
The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells
The presence of renal cell carcinoma in the renal papilla

A type of pituitary adenoma originating in prolactin secreting cells. This kind of adenoma is characterized by overproduction of prolactin, and may cause loss of menstrual periods and breast milk production in women
A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron
A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements
The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton
A non-malignant neoplasm of the genitourinary system
A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism
A kind of thyroid adenoma characterized by the presence of oxyphil cells
Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses
Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders)

concept.display: Loss of ability to walk in first decade

concept.definition: Any anomaly of the anterior horn cell
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the white matter of the central nervous system

concept.display: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region

concept.definition: A type of focal clonic seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking rapidly involves one side of the body at seizure onset
Absence or underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum

A form of lissencephaly in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development. At neuropathological examination, a 4-layered cortex consists of an upper molecular layer, a second thin cellular layer containing pyramidal neurons usually observed in layer V, a third pale poorly cellular layer and a fourth thick deep layer made up of neurons which had failed to migrate. Radiologocally would manifest as agyria or pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm
A type of polymicrogyria with a gradient of severity (anterior more severe than posterior) extending from frontal poles posteriorly to precentral gyrus and inferiorly to frontal operculum

concept.display: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord

concept.definition: A severe degree of muscular hypotonia characterized by markedly reduced muscle tone

concept.display: obsolete Severe neonatal hypotonia in males
Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
concept.definition: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy
A type of Horner syndrome with congenital onset
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella
Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the pons
Multiple neurofibromas of the spinal nerve roots with a symmetric distribution
The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia
Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints
A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts

concept.display: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs

concept.definition: A type of holoprosencephaly in which most of the right and left cerebral hemispheres and lateral ventricles are separated but the most rostral aspect of the telencephalon, the frontal lobes, are fused, especially ventrally
Underdevelopment of the cerebrum
A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system
Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum
A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum
A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system
A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the distal portions of the limbs
The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time
Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-85
Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the frontotemporal cerebrum
The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures that is present already at the time of birth
Atrophy of the frontal cortex

concept.display: Intraaxonal accumulation of curvilinear autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
concept.definition: Curvilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material within axons

concept.display: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior

concept.definition: Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature
Excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of one side of the brain

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cortex of frontal lobe and the cortex of parietal lobe
Nystagmus dating from or present at birth

A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus
A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles
A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration
An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis
Hypoplasia of the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus

An abnormality of the auditory evoked potentials, which are used to trace the signal generated by a sound, from the cochlear nerve, through the lateral lemniscus, to the medial geniculate nucleus, and to the cortex
Proximal spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem
The presence of calcium deposition in the choroid plexus

concept.display: Gait instability, worse in the dark

concept.definition: A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue
Any abnormal alteration of an individual's circadian rhythm that affects the timing of sleeping and being awake
Leukoencephalopathy that gets more severe with time

concept.display: Distal sensory loss of all modalities

concept.definition: A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged

Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium
A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons
Focal proliferation of glial cells in the basal ganglia

concept.display: Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellar vermis

concept.definition: Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg
The formation of small cavities in the tissue of the basal ganglia

An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of small muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Fine motor skills are required to mediate movements of the wrists, hands, fingers, feet, and toes

Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly

An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of large muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Gross motor skills are required to mediate movements of the arms, legs, and other large body parts

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient
Inability to perceive painful stimuli
Cerebral hemorrhage that occurs before birth

Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. Pseudobulbar paralysis is characterized clinically by dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia with bifacial paralysis, and may be accompanied by Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms such as enforced crying and laughing
A morphological abnormality of the metencephalon
A small, sac-like aneurysm (outpouching) of a cerebral blood vessel

The presence of dysplasia (abnormal growth or development) of the cerebellum. Cerebellar dysplasia is a neuroimaging finding that describes abnormalities of both the cerebellar cortex and white matter and is associated with variable neurodevelopmental outcome

concept.display: Symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia

concept.definition: Meningitis that persists for more than 4 weeks, and lymphocytes are present in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
Partial or complete wasting (loss) of dentate nucleus
Increased size of the basal ganglia
Generalized atrophy or hypoplasia of the cerebrum

concept.display: Aplasia of the inferior half of the cerebellar vermis

concept.definition: Progressive loss of previously present language abilities

concept.display: Disorganization of the anterior cerebellar vermis

concept.definition: Peripheral sensory neuropathy affecting primarily distal sensation
Underdevelopment of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum
Increased vertical dimension of the corpus callosum. This feature can be visualized by sagittal sections on magnetic resonance tomography imaging of the brain
Muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement)

concept.display: Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials
concept.definition: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies
An increase in size of the third ventricle
Fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle and the musculature of the face
An excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain in the frontoparietal region
Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements

Arnold-Chiari type I malformation refers to a relatively mild degree of herniation of the posteroinferior region of the cerebellum (the cerebellar tonsils) into the cervical canal with little or no displacement of the fourth ventricle

concept.display: Hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
concept.definition: A darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter
Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers from segments of the peripheral nervous system
Demyelinating neuropathy is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocities with reduced amplitudes of sensory/motor nerve conduction and prolonged distal latencies
Atrophy of the temporal cortex
A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change
Amyotrophy (muscular atrophy) affecting the proximal musculature
Acute progressive areflexic weakness and mild sensory changes resulting from myelin breakdown and axonal degeneration
Neurodegeneration involving the globus pallidus,a part of the basal ganglia that is involved in the regulation of voluntary movement
Muscular atrophy of distal arm muscles
Stiffness of the limbs (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in an asymmetric pattern
A progressive degree of muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement)

concept.display: Diffuse demyelination of the cerebral white matter
concept.definition: A diffuse loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system

concept.display: obsolete Corticospinal tract disease in lower limbs

concept.definition: A form of gray matter heterotopia were the mislocalized gray matter is typically located periventricularly, also sometimes called subependymal heterotopia. Periventricular means beside the ventricles. This is by far the most common location for heterotopia. Subependymal heterotopia present in a wide array of variations. There can be a small single node or a large number of nodes, can exist on either or both sides of the brain at any point along the higher ventricle margins, can be small or large, single or multiple, and can form a small node or a large wavy or curved mass
Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks
A complete lack of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion

Atrophy of the interosseus muscles (including the palmar interossei that lie on the anterior aspect of the metacarpals, the dorsal interosseus muscles of the hand, which lie between the intercarpals, the plantar interosseus muscles, which lie underneath the metatarsal bones, and the dorsal interossei, which are located between the metatarsal bones
Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system

concept.display: Focal T2 hyperintense basal ganglia lesion
concept.definition: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the basal ganglia
A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex
Facial diplegia (that is, bilateral facial palsy) with congenital onset

concept.display: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex

concept.definition: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures on awakening are a form of Generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur upon awaking
Atherosclerosis (HP:0002621) of a cerebral artery
Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere
Generalized-onset tonic-clonic seizures that are provoked by flashing or flickering light
Presence of irregular redundant loops of focally folded myelin in a peripheral nerve
Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve)
Muscular atrophy affecting the lower limb
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with elevated levels of potassium in the blood
Demyelination of peripheral motor nerves
Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum
The presence of calcium deposition in the cerebral white matter surrounding the cerebral ventricles

concept.display: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential
concept.definition: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential in distal nerve segments. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies

concept.display: Spinocerebellar tract disease in lower limbs

concept.definition: Groups of small caliber axons in peripheral nerve biospies indicative of axonal regeneration
A type of gait ataxia displaying progression of clinical severity

concept.display: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers

concept.definition: Alternating and recurrent weakness of the external ocular muscles
Functional neurological abnormalities related to dysfunction of the pyramidal tract

concept.display: Severe demyelination of the white matter
concept.definition: A severe loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system
A form of lissencephaly characterized by an uneven cortical surface with a so called 'cobblestone' appearace. There are no distinguishable cortical layers
A symmetric loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system
Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord
Agenesis of the midbrain
Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths of the white matter of the brain
An abnormality characterized by chronic impairment of the normal functioning of the axons
Muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem

An atypical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by interruption of ongoing activities and reduced responsiveness. In comparison to a typical absence seizure, changes in tone may be more pronounced, onset and/or cessation may be less abrupt, and the duration of the ictus and post-ictal recovery may be longer. Although not always available, an EEG often demonstrates slow (<3 Hz), irregular, generalized spike-wave activity
An increased susceptibility to bacterial meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of bacterial meningitis

concept.display: Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons

concept.definition: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills

concept.display: Facial palsy secondary to cranial hyperostosis
concept.definition: Paralysis of the facial nerves on the basis of overgrowth of the cranial bones causing impingement upon the seventh cranial nerve
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements, in which the movement in one direction is faster than in the other
Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs
A discrete posterior fossa cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collection that does not communicate directly with the fourth ventricle
A loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system
Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the deep cerebral white matter
A type of dystonia that affects all or most of the body
Reduced ability to perceive painful stimuli
Focal seizure characterized at onset by clonic movements affecting half of the face
Underdevelopment of the frontal lobe of the cerebrum

concept.display: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset
concept.definition: A bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset is a focal-onset seizure which progresses into a bilateral tonic-clonic phase
Recurrent episodes of brain dysfunction that may be triggered by factors such as metabolic disturbances or infections
A saccade that overshoots the target with the dynamic saccade
Weakness of the muscles of the legs

concept.display: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter
Abnormal morphology of the limbic system
concept.definition: Any structural anomaly of the limbic system, a set of midline structures surrounding the brainstem of the mammalian brain, originally described anatomically, e.g., hippocampal formation, amygdala, hypothalamus, cingulate cortex. Although the original designation was anatomical, the limbic system has come to be associated with the system in the brain subserving emotional functions. As such, it is very poorly defined and doesn't correspond closely to the anatomical meaning any longer. [BirnLex]
A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position

A focal-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating within networks limited to one hemisphere. They may be discretely localized or more widely distributed, and may originate in subcortical structures
An abnormality of the pons

concept.display: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system

concept.definition: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebrum, also known as the telencephalon, the largest and most highly developed part of the human brain
Absence or underdevelopment of the corpus callosum
The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the corpus callosum
Wasting involving the motor neuron
An abnormality of the septum pellucidum, which is a thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the lateral ventricles of the brain
An abnormality of the choroid plexus, which is the area in the cerebral ventricles in which cerebrospinal fluid is produced by modified ependymal cells

An abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), i.e., of the electrical signals of sensation going from the body to the brain in response to a defined stimulus. Recording electrodes are placed over the scalp, spine, and peripheral nerves proximal to the stimulation site. Clinical studies generally use electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves to elicit potentials. SSEP testing determines whether peripheral sensory nerves are able to transmit sensory information like pain, temperature, and touch to the brain. Abnormal SSEPs can result from dysfunction at the level of the peripheral nerve, plexus, spinal root, spinal cord, brain stem, thalamocortical projections, or primary somatosensory cortex
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the gastrointestinal tract
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genitourinary system
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the face
A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp
Underdevelopment of the sweat glands
A type of ichthyosiform erythroderma with postnatal onset
Photosensitivity of the skin occurring early in life
Developmental hypoplasia of the apocrine sweat glands in the region of the axilla
Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the macula, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss

concept.display: Areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation that do not follow Blaschko lines
Excessive skin wrinkling on dorsum of hands and fingers

concept.definition: Increased susceptibility to infection by the protozan parasite of the genus Leishmania

concept.display: obsolete Absence of subcutaneous fat over entire body except buttocks, hips, and thighs

concept.definition: An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the forehead

concept.display: Neonatal wrinkled skin of hands and feet

concept.definition: Cutaneous lesion that develops as a dry, scaly, red patch that evolves to an indurated and hyperpigmented plaque with adherent scale. Scarring may result in central white patches (loss of pigmentation) and skin atrophy
Loss of all scalp hair
Spontaneous development of hematomas (hematoma) or bruises without significant trauma
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the cheeks
Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the oral mucosa
The presence of two to five cafe-au-lait macules
Generalized abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body
An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin with congenital onset
Hemangioma is a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells. This term refers to facial hemangiomas that have a plaque-like morphology
The presence of multiple leiomyomas of the skin

concept.display: Mottled pigmentation of the trunk and proximal extremities

concept.definition: Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs
A type of blistering that affects the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet

concept.display: Increased groin pigmentation with raindrop depigmentation

concept.definition: Lichenification affecting primarily flexural areas of the skin
Prominent thoracic and abdominal veins
Keratinization of the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus (corneoscleral junction), resulting in a raised spot
Reduced number or density of facial hair
Increased amount of keratin (visible as white scales) surrounding hair follicles
Cutis gyrata of palms and soles
Subcutaneous nodules that are located in the vicinity of joints

concept.display: Axillary and groin hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation

concept.definition: An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin that presents at birth or shortly thereafter with generalized erythema, blistering, erosions, and peeling. In the subsequent months, erythema and blistering improves but patients go on to develop hyperkeratotic scaling that is especially prominent along the joint flexures, neck, hands and feet
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs (fingerprints), which are present on fingers, palms, toes, and soles

The term collodion baby applies to newborns who appear to have an extra layer of skin (known as a collodion membrane) that has a collodion-like quality. It is a descriptive term, not a specific diagnosis or disorder (as such, it is a syndrome). Affected babies are born in a collodion membrane, a shiny waxy outer layer to the skin. This is shed 10-14 days after birth, revealing the main symptom of the disease, extensive scaling of the skin caused by hyperkeratosis. With increasing age, the scaling tends to be concentrated around joints in areas such as the groin, the armpits, the inside of the elbow and the neck. The scales often tile the skin and may resemble fish scales

concept.display: Decreased sweating due to autonomic dysfunction

concept.definition: Lack of subcutaneous adipose tissue
Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) with a diffuse localization

concept.display: Linear arrays of macular hyperkeratoses in flexural areas
Discrete 2 to 5-mm hyper- and hypopigmented macules

concept.definition: Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot in areas exposed to friction
Increased susceptibility to staphylococcal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of staphylococcal infections
The presence of fewer than normal sweat glands

concept.display: Streaks of hyperkeratosis along each finger onto the palm

concept.definition: A skin condition characterized by excessive development of keratin in hair follicles, resulting in rough, cone-shaped, elevated papules resulting from closure of hair follicles with a white plug of sebum

concept.display: Congenital absence of skin of limbs

concept.definition: Tiny bumps of thickened skin (hyperkeratosis) on the palms of the hands

concept.display: Edema of the dorsum of hands
concept.definition: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the hands
Loose and sagging skin of the fingers
Loose, wrinkled skin of hands and feet

concept.display: obsolete Lack of subcutaneous fatty tissue
Yellow subcutaneous tissue covered by thin, scaly skin

concept.definition: Loss of hair in the occipital region of the scalp with congenital onset

concept.display: Aplasia cutis congenita of midline scalp vertex

concept.definition: A severe degree of photosensitivity of the skin
Presence of a cutaneous lipoma on the forehead

concept.display: Absent pigmentation of the ventral chest
concept.definition: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the anterior chest
Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution

concept.display: Palmoplantar keratosis with erythema and scale
Desquamation of skin soon after birth
Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin

concept.definition: Hyperkeratosis affecting the sole of the foot

concept.display: Telangiectases in sun-exposed and nonexposed skin

concept.definition: The presence of six or more cafe-au-lait spots
Seborrheic dermatitis that is not localized to any one particular region

Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans (HLP), also known as Flegel disease, is a keratinization abnormality characterized by small, asymptomatic erythematous papules that leave characteristic punctate bleeding when they become detached. The lesions generally occur symmetrically along the top of the foot and on the legs, appearing more rarely on the arms, forearms, palms, and soles, and even on the oral mucosa
A form of atopic dermatitis with onset in adulthood characterized by atopic red face, chronic lichenified eczema on the trunk, subacute or psoriasiform dermatitis
Increased pigmentation of the skin with a netlike (reticular) pattern

concept.display: Aplasia cutis congenita on trunk or limbs
concept.definition: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the trunk or the limbs

concept.display: Aplasia cutis congenita over posterior parietal area
Aplasia/Hypoplastia of the eccrine sweat glands
concept.definition: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the eccrine sweat glands
The presence of multiple subcutaneous lipoma that cause pain
The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease on both hands
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body because of decreased osmotic pressure of plasma (hypoproteinemia)

concept.display: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles

concept.definition: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the neck. This is one of the most common birthmarks and present in approximately 25% of all newborns
Deposition of calcium salts in subcutaneous tissue (i.e., the the lowermost layer of the integument)
The presence of leiomyoma of the skin
Osteomyelitis of the lower jaw
A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes

An acute condition characterized by sudden visual loss (usually discovered in the morning), optic disc edema at onset, optic disc-related visual field defects. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can be associated with flame hemorrhages on the swollen disc or nearby neuroretinal layer, and sometimes with nearby cotton-wool exudates
A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments
A nonprogressive (i.e., stationary) form of difficulties with night blindness with congenital onset
Tractional retinal detachment at the periphery of the retina
Lack of eyelashes on the lower lid
Congenital abnormality of the extraocular muscles
A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the lens

concept.display: Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
concept.definition: Sharply demarcated, congenital hyperpigmentation of the retinal pigment epithelium

concept.display: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids

concept.definition: A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland
Opacity of the entire lens nucleus

concept.display: obsolete Decreased retinal pigmentation with dispersion

concept.definition: Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes

Degenerative changes of the peripheral retina consisting of close-packed tiny cystic spaces at the outer plexiform/inner nuclear retinal level. The degeneration is very common in adult eyes and starts adjacent to the ora serrata and extends circumferentially and posteriorly

An abnormality of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR). The VOR attempts to keep the image stable on the retina. Ideally passive or active head movements in one direction are compensated for by eye movements of equal magnitude
Congenital underdevelopment of the iris
Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula
Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct)
A functional abnormality of the pupil
A unilateral form of ptosis
Absence of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram
An abnormality of the reflex that controls the diameter of the pupil, in response to the intensity of light that falls on the retina of the eye
Underdevelopment of the lower eyelid
Abnormal development (dysgenesis) of the anterior segment of the eye globe. These structures are mainly of mesenchymal origin
Sudden-onset episode of abnormal, involuntary eye movements
Absence of the crystalline lens of the eye as a result of a developmental defect
A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid)
A chronic irritative conjunctivitis, which commonly presents with general irritation and redness of the eyes, with a burning, dry, or foreign-body sensation of the eyes

Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age
Presence of multiple dilatations (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva
Atrophy (loss or wasting) of the retinal pigment epithelium observed on fundoscopy or fundus imaging
Lack of transparency of the corneal epithelium
Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset
An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the iris
Abnormal development of the choroid and retina
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland
Abnormally big lacrimal glands

concept.display: Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina
concept.definition: Pigment migration into the retina in a bone-spicule configuration (resembling the nucleated cells within the lacuna of bone)
Underdevelopment of the fovea centralis
Macular dystrophy is a nonspecific term for premature retinal cell aging and cell death, generally confied to the macula in which no clear extrinsic cause is evident

concept.display: obsolete Slitlike anterior chamber angles in children

concept.definition: Reduced transparency of the stroma of cornea
A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point
Dilatation of small blood vessels of the retina
Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased
Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve
The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of retinal blood vessels (arteries, arterioles, veins, venules)
An impairment of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion
Ocular abnormality characterised by premature degeneration of the vitreous and the retina that may be associated with increased risk of retinal detachment
Underdevelopment of the ciliary body
Fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound (i.e., a scar) located in the choroid and retina or the eye
A type of retinal neovascularization that affects the posterior pole of the retina
A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens

concept.display: obsolete Butterfly retinal pigment epithelial dystrophy

concept.definition: A type of cataract affecting the posterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the Lens capsule

concept.display: Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
concept.definition: Wasting (atrophy) of the retinal pigment epithelium present in small, isolated areas
Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea
A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens
The presence of whitish deposits in the conjunctiva resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis

concept.display: Increased axial length of the globe
concept.definition: Abnormal largeness of the eye with an axial length > 2.5 standard deviations from population mean

The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material
Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray
Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity

The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining
A form of uveitis that is not associated with the formation of granulomas

Mottling (spots or blotches with different shades) of the retinal pigment epithelium, i.e., localized or generalized fundal pigment granularity associated with processes at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium

concept.display: Abnormal distribution of retinal arterioles and venules

concept.definition: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal
The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone
Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual
Congenital absence or closure of the opening of the lacrimal punctum
Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles

concept.display: obsolete Cataracts develop in second or third decade

concept.definition: Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood

Nonprogressive restriction of movement of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited
A kind of cataract that progresses with age
A progressive form of ptosis
Increased length of the upper eyelashes

concept.display: Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humor
concept.definition: Deposition of hyaline extracellular material (amyloid) into the vitreous humor, which can manifest as vitreous opacities and reduced visual acuity
Punctate opacification (reduced transparency) of the corneal stroma
Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina
Horizontal nystagmus dating from or present at birth
Deposition of calcium salts in the retina
Fibrosis of only some of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position
The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas

A shape created by an acute downward arching of the upper eyelid and upward arching of the lower eyelid, toward the medial canthus, which gives the outline of the palpebral fissures the configuration of an almond. Thus, the maximum distance between the fissures is offset from, and medial to, the center point
Blindness with onset at birth
Allergic Conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva
An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements
Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles
A type of posterior subcapsular cataract characterized by an iridescent color
Underdevelopment of the lacrimal puncta

Reduced pigmentation of the fundus, typically generalised. Fundoscopy may reveal a low level pigment in both RPE and choroid with clear visibility of choroidal vessels (pale/albinoid) or low pigment level in the RPE with deep pigment in choroid so that visible choroidal vessels are separated by deeply pigmented zones (tesselated/tigroid)
Failure of attachment of the retina during development
Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye
Chorioretinal atrophy along the retinal veins
Intraocular pressure that is 2 standard deviations above the population mean
A type of of patterned retinal dystrophy that shows a reticular pattern of pigmentation

This corneal dystrophy affects the posterior limiting membrane of the cornea and is characterized by polymorphous plaques of calcium deposits in the deep stromal layers of the cornea, and occasionally by vesicular lesions of the endothelium and edema of the deep corneal stroma

concept.display: obsolete Small anterior lens surface opacities

concept.definition: A type of retinal detachment arising due to a combination of contracting retinal membranes, abnormal vitreoretinal adhesions, and vitreous changes. It is usually seen in the context of diseases that induce a fibrovascular response, e.g. diabetes
A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct
Anomaly of the visual evoked potentials elicited by a flash stimulus, generally a flash of light subtending an angle of at least 20 degrees of the visual field and presented in a dimly lit room
Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium occuring near the outer limit (periphery) of the retina
Congenital abnormal dilation of the pupil on both sides
Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow
Fibrosis of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited
A type of retinal reticular pigmentation that forms a polygonal, netlike arrangement of hyperpigmented lines forming geometric patterns in the fundus
A form of monochromacy in which vision is derived from the remaining preserved blue (S) cones and rod photoreceptors
Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus
A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset
A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures on one side only

A subtype of retinitis pigmentosa in which, instead of the pathology starting in the mid-periphery like typical retinitis pigmentosa, the disease starts in the near periphery closer to the vascular arcades and tends to spare the far periphery
A type of posterior cortical cataract characterized by dense lenticular opacities
Chorioretinal atrophy concentrated around the optic papilla (i.e., the optic nerve head)
A reduction of corneal clarity

concept.display: Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression

concept.definition: A spectrum of fundoscopic appearances characterized by the development of a variety of patterns of deposits predominantly in the macular area. The deposits are typically bilateral, relatively symmetrical, yellow/white and associated with changes at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium. With time, retinal atrophy may occur. A number of pattern dystrophy subtypes have been described including butterfly-shaped dystrophy, reticular dystrophy (net-like pattern) and fundus pulverulentus (granular, mottled pigmentation)

concept.display: Remnants of the hyaloid vascular system
concept.definition: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth. This features results from a failure of regression of the hyaloid vessel, which supplies the primary vitreous during embryogenesis and normally regresses in the third trimester of pregnancy, leading to a particular form of posterior cataract
A congenital cataract in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina
Saccadic undershoot of horizontal saccadic eye movements, i.e., a horizontal saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object

Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary
Horizontal nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left

concept.display: obsolete Concentric narrowing of visual field

concept.definition: A dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram in which the b-wave that is of markedly lower amplitude than the associated a-wave (source: Holder GE., Inherited Chorioretinal Dystrophies: A Textbook and Atlas; 2014; p.17; ISBN 978-3-540-69466-3)
Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina
Decreased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea
Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself
Underdevelopment of the stroma of iris
Congenital malformation of the lacrimal duct associated with incomplete development of the bony nasolacrimal canal or craniofacial anomalies
Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision

An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids
Increased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis
Abnormality of macular or foveal pigmentation
Reduced transparency of the peripheral region of the cornea

Microscopic aneurysms of the retinal arterioles near the central part of the fundus, visible as small round dark red dots on the retinal surface (not arising from visible vessels) that are by definition less than the diameter of the major optic veins as they cross the optic disc

concept.display: obsolete Depigmented lesions of the retinal pigment epithelium

concept.definition: Partial dislocation of the lens in a superior direction
Inherited progressive cone degeneration
A form of macular degeneration characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the macula
A type of sutural cataract in which the opacity follows the posterior Y suture
Abnormal pigmentation of the iris

Retinitis pigmentosa inversa is form of retinal degeneration characterized by areas of retinal/chorioretinal degeneration with pigment migration in the macular area (in contrast to retinitis pigmentosa which, at early disease stages, predominantly affects the retinal periphery)

concept.display: Absent anterior chamber of the eye
concept.definition: Absence of the anterior chamber of the eye owing to a developmental defect
Absence or underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland
Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina
A structural abnormality of retinal vasculature

concept.display: Abnormality of the vasculature of the eye
Abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
concept.definition: An abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
An abnormality of an extraocular muscle
An anomaly of the space between the medial and lateral canthi of the two open eyelids

concept.display: obsolete Abnormality of the retinal pigment epithelium

concept.definition: A wrinkle of retinal tissue projecting outward from the surface of the retina and visible as a line on fundoscopy
Absence or underdevelopment of the iris

concept.display: Abnormal morphology of the conjunctival vasculature
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva
Absence or underdevelopment of the uvea, the pigmented middle layer of the eye consisting of the iris and ciliary body together with the choroid
Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the fovea centralis

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the anterior segment of the eye
concept.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior segment of the eye
Absence or underdevelopment of the lens
An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization
The presence of one or more bullae on the skin, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skin
Reduced density of hairs
Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy
Virilization (deepening of voice, facial hirsutism and scalp hair loss) with onset during pregnancy (usually towards the end of the first trimester) and regression several months post-partum
An abnormally high concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age
The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age
Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence of the fifth metatarsal bone
Medial deviation of the great toe owing to a deformity of the great toe joint causing the hallux to deviate medially
An outward deviation of the foot at the talocalcaneal or subtalar joint
The presence of a fifth metatarsal bone that has not undergone ossification at an age when ossification is usually visible

concept.display: Abnormality of the fifth metatarsal bone
concept.definition: An anomaly of the fifth metatarsal bone
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the fourth toe
An overall widening of the spaces between the digits
Osteolysis affecting the talus
Medial deviation of the second toe

concept.display: Expanded metatarsals with widened medullary cavities

concept.definition: Delayed maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones

concept.display: Plantar crease between first and second toes
concept.definition: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot located between the first and second toe
Precocious (accelerated) maturation and calcification of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones
Osteosclerosis of the endosteal surface of the diaphyses (shafts) of the metatarsal bones
Bending or curvature of a third toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe)
Limitation of the ability to bend the toes
Synostosis of the calcaneus with the navicular bone
A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus
A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more tarsal bones

concept.display: Medial rotation of the medial malleolus

concept.definition: Defective ossification in an irregular pattern of the seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones

Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees
Delayed maturation and calcification of the calcaneus
Abnormal response to epinephrine as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of epinephrine
Elevations of the levels of SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) that occur during infections

Increased time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT
Episodes of muscle weakness associated with reduced levels of potassium in the blood
Excessive amounts of mucopolysaccharide in the urine
Hyperapobetalipoproteinemia is defined as the combination of a normal low density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the face of an increased LDL apolipoprotein B (apoB) protein
An increase in the level of 3-hydroxydicarboxylic acid in the urine
Alkaline phosphatase levels measured within leukocytes is below detectable levels
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood not associated with symptoms such as encephalopathy
Abnormally reduced concentration of cortisol in the blood
Reduced proportion of helper T cells relative to the total number of T cells
Abnormally decreased rate of beta-galactosidase activity. Beta-galactosidase activity can be measured in leukocyte, fibroblast, or plasma

concept.display: Very long chain fatty acid accumulation

concept.definition: Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X
An abnormal reduction in the Arden ratio, which is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record
An absence of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood
The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys
The presence of large polyhedral cells with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei in the adrenal cortex
No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty
Decreased sensitivity toward insulin
The congenital absence of the thyroid gland
The presence of multiple pancreatic islet cell adenomas
Deficiency of parathyroid hormone with congenital onset
A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia
