A reduced level of prolactin in the blood circulation. Prolactin is a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production

concept.display: Precocious puberty with Sertoli cell tumor

concept.definition: Ketosis-resistant diabetes is a synonym for type II diabetes. This term thus refers to a form of type II diabetes in which patients are dependent on insulin
Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves
Hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland

Amenorrhea due to loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. Primary ovarian inssuficiency (POI) is a state of female hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. It can manifest as primary amenorrhea with onset before menarche or secondary amenorrhea
Aplasia of the parathyroid gland

A reduced ability to secrete gonadotropins, which are protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary gland, including the hormones follitropin (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)
A reduction below normal concentration of estradiol in the circulation
Abnormal development of the adrenal gland
Enlargement of the adrenal gland
Condition associated with a raised serum concentration of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) but a normal serum free thyroxine (FT4)
Insufficient amount of androgenic activity

A condition in which the pituitary gland is partially resistant to thyroid hormone, so that it continues to secrete thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) until the blood level of thyroid hormone rises higher than normal
The presence of lymphangiectasis of the thyroid gland

concept.display: Elevated circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
concept.definition: An elevated concentration of follicle-stimulating hormone in the blood
An reduced concentration of progesterone in the blood
A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in thyrotropin-releasing hormone activity
Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal medulla
A state of renal tubular unresponsiveness or resistance to the action of aldosterone
A type of adrenal hypoplasia with congenital onset
A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in thyroid-stimulating hormone secretion
An abnormality of thyroid physiology (HP:0002926) characterized by increased levels of thyroxine without evidence of clinical thyroid disease
Hyperplasia of the thyroid gland
An enlargement of the thyroid gland with congenital onset
Adrenocortical adenomas are benign tumors of the adrenal cortex
A type of adrenal hyperplasia with congenital onset
Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the ACTH receptor
The presence of an adenoma of the pancreas with origin in a pancreatic B cell

concept.display: Thyroid defect in oxidation and organification of iodide

concept.definition: The presence of intracellular inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in neutrophils. Cytoplasmic neutrophil inclusions (oval, basophilic) are also known as Doehle bodies

concept.display: Increased red cell hemolysis by shear stress

concept.definition: Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. A number of abnormalities may be appreciated by electron micrography or biochemical investigations, including sparse collagen fibers in the cartilage matrix
An abnormality of zinc ion homeostasis
Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellar cortex
An increased concentration of ammonia in the blood with sudden onset
An increased amount of unconjugated (indirect) bilurubin in the blood
An increased concentration of insulin in the blood in the fasting state, i.e., not as the response to food intake
A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor H in circulation
A type of pituitary adenoma that produces adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)
An increase in the level of long-chain dicarboxylic acid in the urine

A condition of not having consistently high levels of phenylalanine in the blood but of experiencing temporary hyperphenylalaninemia following ingestion of large quantities of phenylalanine (for instance, following an oral loading test with phenylalanine)
An increased concentration of dermatan sulfate in the urine
Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata
Presence of myoglobin in the urine following exercise
An increase in the level of medium chain dicarboxylic acid in the urine

concept.display: Spinal cord posterior columns myelin loss
Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex II
concept.definition: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex II, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria
A decreased concentration of free (unbound) carnitine in the blood
An abnormality of the mitochondria in muscle tissue
Increased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes
Abnormal response to collagen or collagen-mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition collagen or collagen-mimetics

Reduced activity of coagulation factor X. The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways converge at factor X (fX). The extrinsic pathway activates fX by means of d factor VII with its cofactor, tissue factor. The intrinsic pathway activates fX by means of the tenase complex (Ca2+ and factors VIIIa, IXa and X) on the surface of activated platelets. Factor Xa in turn activates prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin (factor IIa)
Any structural anomaly of the mitochondria
An abnormality of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram
An abnormally decreased concentration of vitamin B6 in the blood circulation
The presence of microscopic crystalline calcium precipitates in the form of oxalate and/or phosphate in the renal parenchyma
Decreased activity of von Willebrand factor. Von Willebrand factor mediates the adhesion of platelets to the collagen exposed on endothelial cell surfaces
An increased concentration of an amino acid in the urine, due to a decreased kidney functionality

concept.display: Partial functional complement factor D deficiency
concept.definition: A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor D in circulation

A type of renal tubular acidosis characterized by a failure of acid secretion by the alpha intercalated cells of the cortical collecting duct of the distal nephron. The urine cannot be acidified below a pH of 5.3, associated with acidemia and hypokalemia

concept.display: Elevated plasma branched chain amino acids
concept.definition: An increased concentration of a branched chain amino acid in the blood

concept.display: Hypoplasia of the iris dilator muscle
concept.definition: Underdevelopment of the dilatator pupillae

concept.display: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex IV
concept.definition: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria
A reduction in immunoglobulin levels of the IgG2 subclass in the blood circulation

An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation

The presence of an abnormally increased concentration of neutral amino acids in the urine. The neutral amino acids are tryptophan, alanine, asparagine, glutamine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, phenylalanine, serine, threonine, tyrosine and valine
Reduced ability to transform factor X into its activated form factor Xa
Decreased activity of coagulation factor XIII (also known as fibrin stabilizing factor). Activated Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers solidifying the clot
An increased concentration of proline in the blood
A neonatal decreased concentration of proteins in the blood
Absence or underdevelopment of the big toe
Absence or underdevelopment of the tarsal bones
An abnormality of the calcaneus, also known as the heel bone, one of the or heel bone, one of the components of the tarsus of the foot which make up the heel
An abnormality of the talus

concept.display: Contractures involving the joints of the feet

concept.definition: Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the tarsus (calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, cuneiiform bones)
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones

Any abnormal process of ossification of the metatarsal bones, which normally are each ossified from two centers: one for the body, and one for the head (metatarsal II,III,IV, and V) and one for the body and one for the base (metatarsal I). The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years
Nails whose growth is slower than normal
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the nail
An anomaly of the toenail

concept.display: Recurrent loss of toenails and fingernails
concept.definition: Recurrent loss, or shedding, of the nails of the fingers and toes
The presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, often with accumulation of soft, yellow keratin between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed, resulting in elevation of the nail plate
A thickening of the stratum corneum in the region beneath the nails

concept.display: Congenital curved nail of fourth toe

concept.definition: Chronic infection of the nails by Candida species
A nail of the fifth finger that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail of little finger
A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails
Detachment of the distal fingernails from the nail bed
Thickened toenails
Longitudinal, linear prominences in the fingernail plate

Onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) refers to nail changes apart from changes of the color (nail dyschromia) and involves partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate
Small, underdeveloped vertebral bodies
The presence of degenerative changes of intervertebral disk
The presence of punctiform calcification of the bone of the vertebral bodies
An abnormal shape of the vertebral bodies whereby the vertebral bodies are thick on one side and taper to a thin edge at the other
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the vertebral column
Schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies
Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies of the lumbar spine
An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L1 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front)

concept.display: Absent in utero ossification of vertebral bodies

concept.definition: A morphological abnormality of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine
Any abnormality of the atlas and the axis
The presence of one or more herniated nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disk
Excessive growth of the bones of the vertebral bodies
An abnormality of the shape of vertebrae, such that they are wedge-shaped (narrow towards the back)
An abnormal narrowing of the cervical spinal canal

A reduction of the distance between vertebral pedicles, which are the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the vertebral body, at the junction of its posterior and lateral surfaces
Over curvature of the lumbar region

A developmental defect of the sacrum characterized by partial or disordered development of the sacrum in which portions of the sacrum, which normally is formed by fusion of five sacral vertebrae S1-S5, fail to form or fail to form normally
A partial dislocation of the intervertebral joint between the second and third cervical vertebrae

Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column. Note that normally, the interpedicular distances get progressively wider as one proceeds down the spine
A progressive form of scoliosis with congenital onset
Agenesis of one or more vertebrae of the cervical vertebral column

concept.display: Absent spinous processes of lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae

concept.definition: A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies
Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the thoracic spine
An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of sacral vertebrae during development
Dysplasia of the cervical vertebral column
A reduction of the distance between the lower thoracic vertebral pedicles
An abnormal reduction of the anterioposterior diameter of the vertebral body
Decreased ossification of the cervical vertebral bodies, i.e., of the Cervical vertebrae set
The presence of arthrosis, i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the cervical vertebral column

concept.display: Cervical vertebral bodies with decreased anteroposterior diameter

concept.definition: A reduction of the distance between thoracolumbar vertebral pedicles

Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus
A developmental anomaly of the ureter
Absence of sex glands (gonads are the organs that produce gametes; testis in males and ovary in females)

Displacement of the thumb from its normal position

concept.display: Complete duplication of distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Complete duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side

concept.display: Complete duplication of proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Partail or complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone

concept.display: Bifid distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones

concept.display: Duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side

concept.display: Duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Bifid proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is partially duplicated. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx) to a partially fused appearance of the two bones. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Complete duplication of the first metacarpal
concept.definition: Complete duplication of the first metacarpal bone
Partial duplication of the first metacarpal bone

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Any anomaly of the distal phalanx of thumb

concept.display: Abnormality of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: An anomaly of the shape or form of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: obsolete Radial deviation of the thumb
obsolete Ulnar deviation of the thumb

concept.definition: Insertion of thumb at a more distal location than normal
Proximal mislocalization of the thumb

concept.display: Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb
concept.definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is formed by the first metacarpal and the trapezial bone and is also called Articulatio carpometacarpalis pollicis, carpometacarpal articulation of thumb, carpometacarpal joint of thumb or first carpometacarpal articulation. Seldom referred to as thumb saddle joint

concept.display: Contractures of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb
concept.definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio metacarpophalangealis pollicis

concept.display: Contractures of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb
concept.definition: Chronic loss of joint motion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio interphalangealis pollicis

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: This term applies if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is either small/hypoplastic or absent. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Broad proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Increased width of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Bullet-shaped proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Bullet-shaped phalanx refers to a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction. This term is used if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is affected

concept.display: Curved proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A deviation from the normal straight shape of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Osteolytic defect of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Patchy sclerosis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: An uneven increase in bone density of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
Fusion of a phalanx of the thumb with another bone

concept.display: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Triangular shaped proximal phalanx of the thumb

Absence of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

Hypoplastic (short) proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Synostosis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal
concept.definition: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the distal phalanx of the thumb
Broad distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Increased width of the distal phalanx of thumb

concept.display: Bullet-shaped distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Bullet-shaped phalanx refers to a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction. This term is used if the distal phalanx of the thumb is affected

concept.display: Curved distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A deviation from the normal straight shape of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Osteolytic defect of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Patchy sclerosis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: An uneven increase in bone density of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Triangular shaped distal phalanx of the thumb. A triangular or so called delta shaped phalanx is a typical result after a bracket epiphysis of the affected phalanx

concept.display: Aplasia of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Absence of the distal/terminal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Short distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Hypoplastic (short) distal phalanx of the thumb
An abnormal morphology of one or more phalanges of the thumb, with a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction
A deviation from the normal straight shape of a thumb phalanx
Dissolution or degeneration of bone tissue of one or more phalanges of the thumb
An uneven increase in bone density of one or more of the phalanges of the thumb
Congenital fusion (ankylosis) of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb
Abnormal shape of one or more phalanges of the thumb such that affected phalanges resemble a triangle

concept.display: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the thumb

concept.definition: The absence of a phalangeal segment of a thumb
Hypoplastic (short) thumb phalanx

concept.display: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb. This epiphysis is located on the proximal end of the phalanx

concept.display: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: This term applies if the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, which is located at the proximal end of the phalanx, does not appear in concordance with gender and age dependant norms as seen on x-rays. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Absent epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Bracket epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: An abnormality of the proximal phalanx of the thumb in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side

concept.display: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the middle phalanx of the thumb of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Enlarged epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb having multiple bony fragments

concept.display: Irregular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Irregular radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Ivory epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays

concept.display: Pseudoepiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Small epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms

concept.display: Stippling of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Triangular epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

concept.display: Absent epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Absence of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Bracket epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: An abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side

concept.display: Cone-shaped epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb of the hand, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of the phalanx

concept.display: Enlarged epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Abnormally large size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms

concept.display: Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb having multiple bony fragments

concept.display: Irregular epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Uneven radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Ivory epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Sclerosis of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays

concept.display: Pseudoepiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Small epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: Abnormally small size of the epiphysis located at the proximal end of the distal phalanx of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms

concept.display: Stippling of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb

concept.display: Triangular epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb
concept.definition: A triangular appearance of the epiphysis of the distal phalanx of the thumb of the hand. This epiphysis is located at the proximal end of the phalanx and is normally nearly flat
Absence of one or more epiphyses of the thumb
An abnormality of the thumb in which the epiphysis surrounds a phalangeal bone, having a bracket-like form and reaching from the proximal side of a phalanx to the distal side

A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphyses of the thumb, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance. The related entity 'angel-shaped' epiphysis refers to a pronounced cone-shaped epiphysis in combination with a pseudoepiphysis at the distal end of a phalanx
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
Epiphysis of the thumb having multiple bony fragments
Uneven radiographic opacity of the one or more epiphyses of the thumb
Sclerosis of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
A pseudoepiphysis (which is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis) of one or more phalanges of the thumb
Abnormally small size of one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb with respect to age-dependent norms
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more of the epiphyses of the thumb

concept.display: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
concept.definition: Chronic loss of joint motion in one or more distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers

concept.display: Osteolytic defects of the hand bones

concept.definition: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term

Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx)
Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform)

Fusion of the 1st metacarpal with another bone. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2 to 5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits
Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter
Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks
A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics
A hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord
An abnormality of the epididymis
A cystadenoma, an epithelial tumor, that originates within the head of the epididymis

Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter

Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients

A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis

The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin

A plaque representing a connective-tissue nevus. Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. Shagreen patches are oval-shaped and nevoid, skin-colored or occasionally pigmented, smooth or crinkled, The word shagreen refers to a type of roughened untanned leather
The presence of small depressions in the dental enamel
A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail
The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary bladder
The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney
Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina
A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle
A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle
A benign tumor of striated muscle
The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum
A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure
The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes)
A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm
Neurofibromas originating in the spine
Pseudarthrosis, or
The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris.

concept.definition: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands
The absence of all phalanges of all the digits of a limb and the associated soft tissues
Absent thumb, i.e., the absence of both phalanges of a thumb and the associated soft tissues
Hypoplasia (congenital reduction in size) of the thumb

A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape
Absence or underdevelopment of the biceps muscle

A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5

A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft

A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region

Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear
A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities
The presence of two or more accessory spleens

Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes

concept.display: Aplasia of the phalanges of the hand
concept.definition: Absence of one or more of the phalanges of the hand
Short (hypoplastic) phalanx of finger, affecting one or more phalanges
The presence of a reduced number of teeth as in Hypodontia or as in Anodontia
A form of heart failure characterized by reduced cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure owing to ischemic heart disease, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, and other causes
A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP)

concept.display: Anomaly of the upper limb diaphyses

An anomaly of one or more metaphyses of the arms

Peromelia affecting only the upper limbs. That is, the distal parts of the arm are missing leading to stump formation

Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course
A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution

concept.definition: This term applies if one or more of the distal phalanges of the hand are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated
A reduction in diameter of the distal phalanx of finger towards the distal end

Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair
An abnormality of hair pigmentation (color)

Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair
Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution

Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella
Flatness of the supraorbital portion of the frontal bones
Complete absence of any auricular structures
The presence of telangiectasia of the ear
Increased thickness of the external ear

concept.display: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
concept.definition: An abnormality of the crus of the helix, which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear
An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch

An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix. That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly
Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix. That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average
The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix. That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix
A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound
Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds
A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length
Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye
Abnormally prominent ear helix
Decreased thickness of the helix of the ear
Absence or underdevelopment of the ear lobes
Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward
Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe
An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly

concept.display: Aplasia of the middle ear ossicles
concept.definition: Absence of the middle ear ossicles, malleus, incus, and stapes
Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple
An abnormality of the tragus
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the tragus
Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose
The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea
Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease
The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil
A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris
A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina
A dermal melanocytic hamartoma that presents as bluish hyperpigmentation on the face along the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Nevus of Ota may involve the sclera
A condition associated with a limitation of the horizontal ocular movement with retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adductio

concept.display: Vascular remnant arising from the disc
concept.definition: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth
Underdevelopment or absence of the nose or parts thereof
Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye)
Complete absence of all nasal structures
Increase in bulk of the ala nasi
An abnormality of the columella
Asymmetry or size difference between the left and right nostril
Increased aperture of the nostril
The presence of only a single nostril
Slender, slit-like aperture of the nostril
The presence of more than two nostrils
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal septum
Abnormally narrow nasal septum
Excess facial hair
Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible
Absence of the mandible
Lack of symmetry between the left and right mandible
The presence of an asymmetric mouth

Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits

A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism

A partial duplication, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance, affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a complete duplication there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones

This term applies if one or more of the phalanges of the 2nd finger are either partially duplicated, depending on severity leading to a broad or bifid appearance of the phalanges, or completely duplicated

Any abnormality of the third metacarpal bone

concept.display: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
concept.definition: In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits). The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end (as seen in the proximal phalanges of the other digits), whereas the epiphyses of the other metacarpal bones are located at the distal end. This term applies if the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal is in any way abnormal, referring to age and gender depending norms, as seen on x-rays

An epiphysis that curves around from its transverse orientation to a longitudinal one from proximal to distal along one side of the phalanx, thus resembling the letter 'C' and forming a bracket around the diaphysis. This results in a so called delta phalanx characterized by a triangular or trapezoidal shaped bone with a C-shaped epiphyseal plate
A cone-shaped appearance of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal, producing a 'ball-in-a-socket' appearance
Abnormally large size of the epiphyses of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms

concept.display: Fragmentation of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
concept.definition: Epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal having multiple bony fragments
Uneven radiographic opacity of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
The epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal are hard and dense like ivory. Such an epiphysis has a uniformly dense appearance on radiographs
The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone although an accessory epiphysis may be located at the distal end of the metacarpal
Abnormally small size of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal with respect to age-dependent norms

concept.display: Epiphyseal stippling of the first metacarpal
concept.definition: The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in the epiphyses of the first metacarpal bone

Aplasia or Hypoplasia affecting the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits)

concept.definition: Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth
A gap in the lower lip

Height of the vermilion of the medial part of the lower lip more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the lower lip in the frontal view (subjective)

Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges
Any abnormality of the salivary glands, the exocrine glands that produce saliva

concept.display: Cleft of alveolar ridge of maxilla
concept.definition: A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges, which are the protuberances in the mouth that contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth. An alveolar cleft can affect all structures of the alveolar ridge, including the gingiva, other mucosa, periosteum, alveolar bone, and teeth

Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective)

A structural abnormality of the interventricular septum

In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the fibular side of the foot, next top the little toe), preaxial (on the tibial side of the foot, next to the big toe) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between big and little toe), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200)

In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200)
A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes
A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side
The retrograde (backwards) flow of blood through the pulmonary valve into the right ventricle during diastole

An ostium primum atrial septal defect is located in the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum. The ostium primum refers to an anterior and inferior opening (ostium) within the septum primum, which divides the rudimentary atrium during fetal development. The ostium primum is normally sealed by fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions around 5 weeks' gestation. Ostium primum defects result from a failure of the fusion of the embryologic endocardial cushion and septum primum
A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart
An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin
A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon
An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus
Absence or underdevelopment of the spleen
An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen
Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology
The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum
An exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance
An abnormality of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium

concept.display: obsolete Widening of the sacrosciatic notch

concept.definition: Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized
The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism
Abnormality of the female genital system
Abnormality of the male genital system
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ovary
Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary

A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells
The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls
Absence or underdevelopment of the testes
Testis not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal canal
The presence of more than two testes
Increased urinary excretion of oligosaccharides (low molecular weight carbohydrate chains composed of at least three monosaccharide subunits), derived from a partial degradation of glycoproteins

An abnormality in the synthesis or catabolism of heme. Heme is composed of ferrous iron and protoporphyrin IX and is an essential molecule as the prosthetic group of hemeproteins such as hemoglobin, myoglobin, mitochondrial and microsomal cytochromes
Abnormally increased excretion of porphyrins in the urine
Buildups of minerals that form in the urinary bladder
Cloacal exstrophy is a severe anterior abdominal wall defect in which the two hemibladders are visible and are separated by a midline intestinal plate, an omphalocele, and an imperforate anus
Absence or underdevelopment of the urinary bladder
Aplasia (absence) of the urinary bladder
Abnormality of the urachus
Persistence of the urachal canal resulting in a canal between the bladder and the umbilicus
The presence of an abnormal connection between the urethra and another organ or the skin
The presence of an abnormal membrane obstructing the urethra
Shortening of the arms predominantly affecting terminal parts of the arm in relation to the upper and middle limb segments
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the arms
Abnormal increase in size of the upper limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells)
The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion
An abnormality of the hypothenar eminence, i.e., of the muscles on the ulnar side of the palm of the hand (i.e., on the side of the little finger)
Reduced muscle mass on the ulnar side of the palm, that is, reduction in size of the hypothenar eminence
Absence or underdevelopment of the palmar creases
The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease)
An abnormality of the creases of the skin of palm of hand
A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit
Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are referred to as
An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones
Shortening of the legs predominantly affecting terminal parts of the leg in relation to the upper and middle arm segments
Amniotic constriction rings affecting the legs
Abnormal increase in size of the lower limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells)
A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together
A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood

The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella
The ability of the knee joint to extend beyond its normal range of motion (the lower leg is moved beyond a straight position with respect to the thigh)
An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility
A bending or abnormal curvature of the fibula
Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition
An abnormal increase in the length of the tibia
An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the ankle joint
An abnormality of dermatoglyphs on the toes and soles, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of sole of foot
A difference in size or shape between the left and right foot
A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight
Absence of the tarsal bones
An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion
Toes that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot
Calcification within the adrenal glands
Deposition of calcium salts in the pituitary gland

Hypersecretion of one or more pituitary hormones. This can occur in conditions in which deficiency in the target organ leads to decreased hormonal feedback, or as a primary condition most usually in connection with a pituitary adenoma
Absence or underdevelopment of the thymus
Enlargement of the thymus

The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend
An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct
An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements
Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs

A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent)
An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read

Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions
An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others

A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment

Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit
Inability to recognize faces of familiar persons
The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person
Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate

Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia
Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo
The combination of pendular nystagmus, head nodding, and torticollis
A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information

An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep
Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles
An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure)
An abnormally small sella turcica
The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium
A degree of pneumatization that is increased compared to age-related norms

The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction
Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components
Bursts of large-amplitude multidirectional saccades without intersaccadic interva

Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus
Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone

Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG

A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation
A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object)

concept.display: Weakness due to upper motor neuron dysfunction
concept.definition: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts is related to a lesion in the corticospinal, corticobulbar or brainstem descending (subcorticospinal) neurons
Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities
Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength

An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications

A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers
A finger resting on the dorsal surface of an adjacent digit when the hand is at rest
An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum
An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum)
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles
An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the ribs

A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation
This term applies if the Epiglottis is absent or hypoplastic

A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin, e.g., exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes, e.g., neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma

Y-shaped metatarsals are the result of a partial fusion of two metatarsal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metatarsals may be seen in combination with polydactyly
A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye
Elevated 7-dehydrocholesterol levels
An abnormally low concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age
An abnormal elevation of phytanic acid

concept.display: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the femoral head
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the femur
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the femoral head
A cystic lesion originating within the brain

Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery
Increased size of epiphyses
An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance
Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays
Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses

Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at each end of a long bone, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal femoral epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the femur

concept.display: Abnormality of the proximal tibial epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the tibia

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal tibial epiphysis
Abnormality of the proximal fibular epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the fibula

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal fibular epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the fibula

concept.display: Abnormality of the proximal radial epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the radius

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal radial epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the radius

concept.display: Abnormality of the proximal humeral epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the humerus

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal humeral epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the humerus

concept.display: Abnormality of the distal ulnar epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the ulna

concept.display: Abnormality of the proximal ulnar epiphysis
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the ulna
An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy)

A benign uni- or multicystic, intraosseous tumor of odontogenic origin, with a characteristic lining of parakeratinized stratified squamous epithelium and potential for aggressive, infiltrative behaviour

A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes

An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling

Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling

Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling

Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region
The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot
Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term
Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels
The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule
A fibroma of the heart
The presence of a fibroma of the ovary
A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components
Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face

A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skeleton
Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail
Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland, also known as the adenohypophysis
Absence of the anterior pituitary gland resulting from a developmental defect
Underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland

Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form

concept.display: Abnormal morphology of the cortex of the humerus
concept.definition: Any abnormality affecting the cortex of the humerus
Any abnormality of a metatarsal bone epiphysis

concept.display: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
concept.definition: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the feet
Inability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation
Inability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants)
Reduced ability to detect any qualitative olfactory sensation
Reduced ability to perceive certain odorants (implies that the sense of smell is maintained for other classes of odorants)
The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area
A form of amyloidosis that affects the conjunctiva

concept.display: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
concept.definition: An abnormally increased level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood

concept.display: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
concept.definition: An abnormally increased level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood
Abnormality of the nasal cavity (the cavity includes and starts at the nares and reaches all the way through to the and includes the choanae, the posterior nasal apertures)
Abnormality of the midnasal cavity which includes the cavity between the nares and the choanae
Absence or abnormal closure of the midnasal cavity
Abnormal narrowing (stenosis) of the midnasal cavity, i.e., of the middle nasal meatus, which in neonates can cause respiratory distress

concept.display: Aplasia of the distal phalanges of the toes
concept.definition: Absence of the distal phalanges of the toes
An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine
Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity
An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility

An abnormal degree of flatness of the Ala of nose, which can be defined as a reduced nasal elevation index (lateral depth of the nose from the tip of the nose to the insertion of the nasal ala in the cheek x 100 divided by the side-to-side breadth of the nasal alae)

An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures
An abnormality of the Meninges, including any abnormality of the Dura mater, the Arachnoid mater, and the Pia mater
An abnormality of the Dura mater
An abnormality of the Falx cerebri
A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri
The presence of abnormal punctate (speckled, dot-like) calcifications in one or more epiphyses
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of an epiphysis

concept.display: Patchy reduction of bone mineral density
concept.definition: Patchy (irregular) reduction in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays

concept.display: Patchy changes of bone mineral density
concept.definition: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density. These changes can either be patchy reduction or increase of mineral density as seen on x-rays. Depending on the pathomechanism and the underlying disease, these changes can either appear solely as reduction or increase or as a combination of both (patches of bone showing an increased density while others are affected by reduction of mineral density)

concept.display: Patchy variation in bone mineral density
concept.definition: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density with patches of bone showing an increased density side to side with patches that are affected by reduction of mineral density. This is sometimes referred to as a moth-eaten appearance on x-rays
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of hand

concept.display: Absence of the third cerebral ventricle
concept.definition: A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the Third ventricle
An abnormality of the Diencephalon, which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain
An abnormality of the thalamus

concept.display: Fusion of the left and right thalami
