concept.definition: A developmental defect characterized by fusion of the left and right halves of the thalamus
The presence of bilateral coxa valga

concept.display: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
concept.definition: Underdevelopment of the anterior nasal spine of maxilla
A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla
An abnormality of the zygomatic bone
Underdevelopment of the zygomatic bone. That is, a reduction in size of the zygomatic bone, including the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms part of the zygomatic arch

concept.display: Abnormality of the third metatarsal bone
concept.definition: An abnormality of the third metatarsal bone

concept.display: Abnormality of the curvature of the vertebral column
concept.definition: The presence of an abnormal curvature of the vertebral column
An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the skeleton of foot
Enuresis occurring during sleeping hours
Enuresis occurring during waking hours of the day
An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood

concept.display: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of renal origin
concept.definition: An abnormally increased level of kidney isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood
An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, intestinal type in the blood
An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, placental type in the blood
An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood

concept.display: Low alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
concept.definition: An abnormally reduced level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood

concept.display: Low alkaline phosphatase of renal origin
concept.definition: An abnormally reduced level of kidney isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood

concept.display: Low alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
concept.definition: An abnormally reduced level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood
An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, intestinal type in the blood
An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, placental type in the blood

A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes
Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the hands only
Mirror image duplication of digits affecting the feet
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five
A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally
A Lamellar cataract with a pulverulent (punctate,
A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture
A type of Congenital cataract in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens
A type of anterior polar cataract which projects as a conical opacity into the anterior chamber
A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital dust-like (pulverulent) opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus
A nuclear cataract with a triangular form
An abnormal deviation from normal levels of immunoglobulins in blood
An increased level of gamma globulin (immunoglobulin) in the blood
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to three
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to four
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand)
Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four
Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three to five
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one and two
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to four
Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to five (complete syndactyly of all toes of the foot)
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to four
Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to five
Syndactyly with fusion of toes three to five
Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are referred to as
An abnormality of the texture of the hair
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth
An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair)
An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear

concept.display: Advanced pneumatization of the mastoid process
concept.definition: An abnormally advanced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms
Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers
Rupture of the eyeball not due to trauma
A developmental defect characterized by absence of the retina

concept.display: Cherry red spot of the macula
concept.definition: Pallor of the perifoveal macula of the retina with appearance of a small circular reddish choroid shape as seen through the fovea centralis due to relative transparancy of the macula
This may present as a partial or complete duplication of the eyebrows

concept.display: Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid
concept.definition: The eyebrows extend towards - or even all the way down to - the margin of the upper eyelid

Nodular changes affecting the eyelids may have many different causes such as cystic lesions (chalaziae, hordeolae), lipogranulomas, melanomas, infectious diseases (Molluscum contagiosum) and many more
Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the eyelid

Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia)
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome
Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone

Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake

A lamellar pattern visible on radiographs and mainly localized at the metaphyses of the long tubular bones. Pathologic-anatomical studies revealed that these benign signs on x-rays are the result of a juvenile metaphyseal bone necrosis. Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance
An abnormal accumulation of excess fluid in the lower extremity resulting in swelling of the feet and extending upward to the lower leg
An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin of the arms
Diminished length of a metatarsal bone, with resultant proximal displacement of the associated toe
A developmental abnormality characterized by the absence (aplasia) of a metatarsal bone

concept.display: Aplasia of the phalanges of the toes
concept.definition: Absence of a digit or of one or more phalanges of a toe

concept.display: Hypoplasia of the phalanges of the toes

concept.definition: An abnormal distribution of eyebrow hair growth in the medial direction
Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid

Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads
Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge
A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin
Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues
An anomaly of the temporomandibular joint
Asymmetry between the left and right sides of the maxilla
Absence or underdevelopment of the premaxilla
Absence of the premaxilla, which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla

An abnormality of the premaxilla, the most anterior part of the maxilla that usually bears the central and lateral incisors and includes the anterior nasal spine and inferior aspect of the piriform rim. The premaxilla contains the bone and teeth of the primary palate
Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla
Aplasia of a toe. That is, absence of all phalanges of a non-hallux digit of the foot and the associated soft tissues
Increased width of the columella

A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis
Insertion of the posterior columella below the nasal base
Decreased length of the eyelashes (subjective)
Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand
Deposition of calcium salts in a tissue or location in which calcification does not normally occur
The presence of a cyst, fistula, or abscess in the sacrococcygeal region (gluteal crease) characteristically accompanied by hair and skin folds
A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris
A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region

A developmental defect characterized by abnormal connection of one or more pulmonary veins to the superior or inferior vena cava, the right atrium, or the coronary sinus, resulting in a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood
A form of anomalous pulmonary venous return in which not all pulmonary veins drain abnormally. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return frequently involves one or both of the veins from one lung
The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name)

A developmental defect of the aortic arch system in which the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches. This occurs if the normal process of regression and persistence of the bilateral embryonic aortic arches fails
Marked widening of the trachea and major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection
Marked widening of the major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection
Marked widening of the trachea
The presence of an abnormally large pelvis
Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound
Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation
A subtype of skin dimples occurring in the shoulder region
Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a gonad
The presence of a neoplasm of the urinary system
A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genital system
The presence of a neoplasm of the testis
Underdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone
Hypertrophy or overdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone
A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them

Reduced ability affecting mainly visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities)
A glioma affecting the cerebellum
A glioma affecting the brainstem

A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter
Increased focal pigmentation of the vermilion of the lips
A neoplasm of the pineal gland
Lack of paramedian peaks and median notch of the upper lip vermilion

Reduced bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion or commissure)
Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the skin surrounding the vermilion of the lips
Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an everted upper lip
Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base
Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure
Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures
Visible space between the dental arches in occlusion
Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest
Increased width of the uvula (subjective finding)
Increased length of the uvula
Decreased width of the uvula
Decreased length of the uvula
More than two clockwise hair whorls
Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull

A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly
Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood
A type of nevus sebaceous with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color

A generalized tonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, often with neck stiffening without a subsequent clonic phase. The tonic activity can be a sustained abnormal posture, either in extension or flexion, sometimes accompanied by tremor of the extremities

Atonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 seconds, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature

Focal emotional seizure with crying (dacrystic) is characterized by the presence of stereotyped crying, this may be accompanied by lacrimation, sad facial expression and sobbing. The subjective emotion of sadness may or may not be present
Focal emotional seizure with laughing (gelastic) is characterized by bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without appropriate related emotion of happiness, and described as 'mirthless'

A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights
An overlap of the bony plates of the skull in an infant, with or without early closure
Any structural abormality of the fifth cranial nerve

concept.display: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
concept.definition: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve

concept.display: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
concept.definition: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve

concept.display: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
concept.definition: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve
Intermittent clonic or tonic contraction of muscles supplied by facial nerve. Muscles are relaxed in between contractions
A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures
A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus
A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position

Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain
Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger

Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails
A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa
An abnormal concentration of copper
Decreased concentration of ceruloplasmin in the blood
An increased concentration of non ceruloplasmin bound copper in the blood
An increased concentration of copper in the urine
An abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG) and being identified at multiple locations (foci)
Focal (localized) slow activity reflects focal dysfunction, not diffuse dysfunction (i.e., encephalopathy)
Multifocal slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
Diffuse slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

concept.display: EEG with persistent abnormal rhythmic activity

concept.definition: The presence of complexes of slow spikes and slow waves (<2.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)
The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (2.5-3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)
The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (>3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG)

Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes
EEG abnormalities (epileptiform discharges) evoked by flashing lights or black and white striped patterns

concept.display: EEG with periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges
concept.definition: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs)are periodic, lateralized, and epileptiform. PLEDs show a relatively constant interval between discharges (0.5 to 3 seconds)

concept.display: EEG with generalized low amplitude activity
concept.definition: An abnormal generalized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

concept.display: EEG with localized low amplitude activity
concept.definition: An abnormal localized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
Periodically occurring generalized periodic complexes
Periodically recurring abnormalities in the EEG
Epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended
A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed
A kind of breech presentation in which one or both hips are extended and one or both of the fetus' feet are pointing down and entering the birth canal
A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands
A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others
Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34

An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents
An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall

A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts
A type of dyssynergia affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field
A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed

Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms
An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive)
Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord
The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows)

A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract
An abnormal level of a circulating protein in the blood

A type of strabismus in which the fixating eye is always the same one, while the other eye is constantly deviated. Monocular strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times

The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm
The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination)
An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta
A congenital disorder of the pulmonary valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop
A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop
Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs
A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply

A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage
Morbus Koehler is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os naviculare pedis
Morbus Kienboeck is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os lunatum
Morbus Osgood-Schlatter is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Tuberositas tibiae

A developmental growth retardation of the vertebral end plates that may lead to secondary destruction of the vertebral end plates and protrusion of the nucleus pulposus into the vertebral body (so called Schmorl's nodes as seen on x-rays)

concept.display: Abnormal circulating branched chain amino acid concentration
concept.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a branched chain family amino acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of phenylalanine in the blood circulation

concept.display: Abnormal circulating serine family amino acid concentration
concept.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a serine family amino acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of glycine in the blood circulation
An elevated plasma concentration of sarcosine
An elevated urinary concentration of sarcosine
An deviation from the normal concentration of sarcosine in the blood circulation

concept.display: Abnormal circulating aspartate family amino acid concentration
concept.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of an aspartate family amino acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of threonine in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of methionine in the blood circulation

concept.display: Abnormal circulating glutamine family amino acid concentration
concept.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a glutamine family amino acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of glutamine in the blood circulation
An abnormality of a histidine metabolic process
An increased concentration of histidine in the blood
Any deviation from the normal concentration of proline or a proline metabolite in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of lysine in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of arginine in the blood circulation
An increased concentration of valine in the blood
An increased concentration of leucine in the blood
Any deviation from the normal concentration of isoleucine in the blood circulation
An increased concentration of isoleucine in the blood
Any deviation from the normal circulation of valine in the blood circulation

concept.display: Abnormal circulating pyruvate family amino acid concentration
concept.definition: An abnormality of a pyruvate family amino acid metabolic process
An abnormality of an alanine metabolic process
Any deviation from the normal concentration of tyrosine in the blood circulation
An abnormality of a cysteine metabolic process
An abnormality of a homocysteine metabolic process
Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens
A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form
A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens
A type of cataract affecting the anterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the lens capsule
A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens
A kind of nuclear cataract characterized by fiberglasslike or needlelike crystals projecting in different directions, through or close to the axial region of the lens
An abnormality of divalent inorganic cation homeostasis

concept.display: obsolete Increased urinary orotic acid concentration

concept.definition: An abnormality of cation homeostasis

concept.display: Abnormal blood monovalent inorganic cation concentration
concept.definition: An abnormality of monovalent inorganic cation homeostasis
An abnormal concentration of sodium
An abnormality of a nucleobase metabolic process
An increased level of xanthine in the blood circulation
An increased concentration of xanthine in the urine

concept.display: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract
concept.definition: An abnormality of the upper urinary tract

concept.display: Abnormality of the lower urinary tract
concept.definition: An abnormality of the lower urinary tract
An abnormality of the nasal skeleton
An abnormality of the external nose
An abnormality of the nasal bone, comprising the left nasal bone and the right nasal bone
Absence or underdevelopment of the nasal bone
Absence of the nasal bone

A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart
Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone
An abnormality of the renal pelvis

Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement
The presence of dilatation of the renal pelvis

concept.display: Abnormality of ductus venosus blood flow
concept.definition: A first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the ductus venosus

concept.display: Abnormality of the fetal cardiovascular system
concept.definition: An abnormality of the fetal circulation system or fetal echocardiogram

concept.display: Abnormality of umbilical vein blood flow
concept.definition: A first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the umbilical vein
An abnormality of the fourth ventricle
An abnormality of the third ventricle

A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (PMID:16100637)
A form of hydrocephalus in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed
Underdevelopment of the right-sided structures of the heart
The presence of a dilated urinary bladder
Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age
A developmental defect resulting in an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra
A bilateral form of agenesis of the kidney

concept.display: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation of the lung
concept.definition: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) can be diagnosed prenatally if ultrasound shows a cystic or solid lung tumor. A CCAM does not have systemic arterial blood supply (in contrast to bronchopulmonary sequenstration). It is a cystic area within the lung that originates from abnormal embryogenesis
The presence of microscopic cystic masses of nonfunctioning pulmonary tissue that lack an obvious communication with the tracheobronchial tree
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is incorporated into the normal surrounding lung
A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is completely discrete from the normal lung and is surrounded by separate pleura

concept.display: Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
concept.definition: By the 14th week of gestation it is nearly always possible to visualized the fluid-filled fetal stomach bubble on prenatal sonography. This term refers to the absence of a normal fetal stomach bubble on fetal ultrasonography performed at around 16 to 20 weeks' gestation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a long-chain fatty acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of phytanic acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a fatty acid anion in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of carnitine in the blood circulation
An abnormality of liposaccharide metabolism
An abnormality of glycolipid metabolism
An abnormality of an erythrocyte cell surface molecule

concept.display: Absence of Lutheran antigen on erythrocytes
concept.definition: Absence of the Lutheran antigen (a type I integral membrane glycoprotein) from the surface of red blood cells
A kind of anemia characterized by inadequate production of erythrocytes
An abnormality of myeloid leukocytes
A deviation from the normal count of B cells, i.e., the cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells
An abnormal decrease from the normal count of B cells

An abnormal functioning of phagocytosis. Phagocytosis is an elegant but complex process for the ingestion and elimination of pathogens, but it is also important for the elimination of apoptotic cells and hence fundamental for tissue homeostasis. Phagocytosis can be divided into four main steps: (i) recognition of the target particle, (ii) signaling to activate the internalization machinery, (iii) phagosome formation, and (iv) phagolysosome maturation
A functional abnormality of the immune system
An abnormal increase or decrease in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood
An abnormal increase in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood
An abnormal decrease in the level of lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of many (more than three) gene loci

A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of a few gene loci. It is recommended this term be used for traits governed by three loci, although it is noted that usage of this term in the literature is not uniform
A type of multifactorial inheritance governed by the simultaneous action of two gene loci
A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the sex chromosomes
An abnormality of the morphology or counts of the cells that make up the immune system
An abnormality of the extrinsic pathway (also known as the tissue factor pathway) of the coagulation cascade
An abnormality of the intrinsic pathway (also known as the contact activation pathway) of the coagulation cascade

concept.display: Abnormality of the common coagulation pathway
concept.definition: An abnormality of blood coagulation, common pathway

concept.display: Abnormal morphology of the abdominal musculature
concept.definition: An abnormality of the abdominal musculature
Involuntary urine leakage synchronous with exertion, or actions such as sneezing, or coughing
An abnormality of the cerebral subcortex
Abnormality of the striatum, which is the largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, comprising the caudate, putamen and ventral striatum, including the nucleus accumbens
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a dicarboxylic acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a monocarboxylic acid in the blood circulation

concept.display: Chromosomal breakage induced by ionizing radiation
concept.definition: Increased amount of chromosomal breaks in cultured blood lymphocytes or other cells induced by treatment with ionizing radiation

concept.display: Increased susceptibility to spontaneous sister chromatid exchange
concept.definition: An increase in the number of spontaneous sister chromatid exchanges observed in cell culture of lymphocytes or other cells

An abnormal increase of bone mineral density, that is, of the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones which is often referred to as osteosclerosis. Osteosclerosis can be detected on radiological examination as an increased whiteness (density) of affected bones
Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal
A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters
An abnormality of the systemic arterial tree, which consists of the aorta and other systemic arteries
A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes

concept.display: Abnormal morphology of the musculature of the neck
concept.definition: An abnormality of the neck musculature
The speed at which disease manifestations appear and develop
Sudden appearance of disease manifestations over a short period of time
Slow, creeping onset, slow progress and long continuance of disease manifestations
Somewhat rapid onset and change of disease manifestations
A deviation from the normal concentration of a polysaccharide in the blood circulation
A deviation from the normal concentration of a carbohydrate in the blood circulation
Abnormality of glucose homeostasis
An abnormality of the concentration of glucose in the blood
An abnormality of the concentration of glucose in the urine
An abnormality in a cellular process
An abnormality of the cell cycle
An abnormality of chromosome condensation
An abnormality of the metabolism of mucopolysaccharide

concept.display: Abnormal circulating unsaturated fatty acid concentration
concept.definition: A deviation from the normal concentration of an unsaturated fatty acid in the blood circulation
Any deviation from the normal concentration of a prostaglandin in the blood circulation
An abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
Abnormal functionality of the cardiovascular system
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the vagina
An abnormality of the fallopian tube
An abnormality of blood circulation
The presence of hemorrhage within the body

concept.display: Abnormal blood transition element cation concentration
concept.definition: An abnormality of the homeostasis (concentration) of transition element cation
An abnormality of the homeostasis (concentration) of iron cation
An abnormality of the regulation of body fluids
An impairment of a fructose metabolic process
The presence of amyloid deposition in one or more tissues. Amyloidosis may be defined as the extracellular deposition of amyloid in one or more sites of the body
An abnormality of the cortex of the kidney
An altered ability of the kidneys to void urine and/or specific substances
A decreased rate of urine production
An abnormality of renal absorption
An abnormality of the helix. The helix is the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe

concept.display: Abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct
concept.definition: An abnormality of the intrahepatic bile duct
Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the cervical vertebral column
An abnormal concentration of potassium
An abnormal concentration of corticotropin in the blood
The presence of an altered number of of permanent teeth

concept.display: Agenesis of permanent maxillary central incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of upper secondary incisor

concept.display: Agenesis of primary maxillary central incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of upper central primary incisor

concept.display: Agenesis of primary mandibular central incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of lower primary incisor

concept.display: Agenesis of permanent mandibular central incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of lower secondary incisor

concept.display: Agenesis of primary maxillary lateral incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of one or more maxillary lateral incisor, comprising the maxillary lateral primary incisor

concept.display: Agenesis of permanent maxillary lateral incisor
concept.definition: Agenesis of one or more upper lateral secondary incisor
Agenesis of premolar tooth
Agenesis of maxillary premolar
Agenesis of mandibular premolar
Agenesis of molar tooth
Agenesis of secondary molar tooth

concept.display: Agenesis of first permanent molar tooth
concept.definition: Agenesis of either maxillary first permanent molar or mandibular first permanent molar or both
Agenesis of either mandibular second permanent molar or maxillary second permanent molar
A generalized form of periodontitis
A localized form of periodontitis

concept.display: Dentinogenesis imperfecta limited to primary teeth
concept.definition: Developmental dysplasia of dentin affecting only the primary dentition
An abnormality of the structure or composition of the teeth
Misaligned incisor
An abnormality of morphology of the incisor tooth
The presence of an altered number of the incisor teeth
An abnormal conical morphology of the incisor tooth
The presence of a supernumerary tooth in the midline between the maxillary central incisors
The presence of an odontoma
The presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, tooth or teeth
An abnormality of morphology of molar tooth
An abnormality of morphology of permanent molar
A developmental defect of tooth color
A localized form of developmental hypoplasia of the dental enamel
A green staining of teeth
An abnormality of premolar tooth
An abnormality of molar tooth
An abnormality of canine tooth
A tooth that has not erupted because of local impediments (overcrowding or fibrous gum overgrowth)
An abnormality of morphology of premolar tooth
Increased size of the incisor tooth
An abnormal conical morphology of the primary incisor
An abnormal conical morphology of either maxillary primary incisor tooth or maxillary permanent incisor tooth or both
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by reduced calcification
A form of hypomineralization of enamel characterized by a chalky appearance of the enamel with orange, brown, or white color

concept.display: Dentinogenesis imperfecta of primary and permanent teeth
concept.definition: Developmental dysplasia of dentin or both the primary dentition and the permanent dentition
Talon cusp is an accessory cusp located near the cingulum (the portion of the lingual or palatal aspect of the tooth that forms a convex protuberance at the cervical third of the anatomic crown)
An abnormality of the incisor characterized by invagination of the enamel, giving a radiographic appearance that suggests a tooth within a tooth
A dental anomaly characterized by the presence of a two fused teeth
The union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected dental arch
The development of two teeth from a single tooth bud, leading to a larger fused tooth
Mulberry molars are irregular teeth generally affecting the first molars and are characterized by a grossly deformed crown imitating, as the name implies, the surface of a mulberry
Increased size and molar morphology of premolar tooth
Maxillary teeth cover the mandibular teeth when biting to an increased degree
An abnormal anteroposterior extension of the maxillary teeth beyond the plane of the mandibular teeth upon jaw closure
A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system

A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all age

A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur
Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine
An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the ileum

concept.display: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology
concept.definition: An abnormality of the outflow tract of the left ventricle
An abnormality in the amount of volume occupied by intravascular blood
An increase in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood
An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood
Recurrent episodes of ulceration of the oral mucosa, typically presenting as painful, sharply circumscribed fibrin-covered mucosal defects with a hyperemic border
A recurrent form of sinusitis
A chronic form of sinusitis
An inflammation of the tonsils

concept.display: Abnormality of immune serum protein physiology
concept.definition: An abnormality of the concentration or function of circulating immune proteins

Abnormality of the cytokine levels in the blood, i.e., an abnormality of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells

An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a cytokine (i.e., any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells)
An impairment in the production by leukocytes of NFKB1-dependent cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-alpha
An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a chemokine (a class of cytokines)
An abnormality in the production or cellular release of interferons (a class of cytokines)
An abnormality in the production or cellular release of interleukins (a class of cytokines)

concept.display: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
concept.definition: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of tumor necrosis factor
An abnormality of the nasal dorsum, also known as the nasal ridge
Nasal ridge curving posteriorly to an imaginary line that connects the nasal root and tip
Any morphological abnormality of the skin
Any abnormality of the physiological function of the skin
The presence of inflammation of the skin. That is, an abnormality of the skin resulting from the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes
An abnormality of the morphology of the epidermis
An abnormality of the melanosomes, i.e., of the cellular organelles in which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored within melanocytes (the cells that produce pigment in the dermis)
A significant descent of the kidney as the patient moves from the supine to the erect position
A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area

A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction
A bilateral form of fetal pyelectasis
Any abnormality of the morphology of the major calices or minor calices of the kidney
The presence of a rash (change of color and texture) of the perianal skin

A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection
An abnormally increased sensitivity to the effects of ionizing radiation
Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade
Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the sweat glands
Absence of the sweat glands
Pale reddish slightly elevated papules and plaques of 0.5-3 cm in diameter and not accompanied by pruritus

An abnormality of the skin adnexa (skin appendages), which are specialized skin structures located within the dermis and focally within the subcutaneous fatty tissue, comprising three histologically distinct structures: (1) the pilosebaceous unit (hair follicle and sebaceous glands); (2) the eccrine sweat glands; and (3) the apocrine glands
Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach
A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus
A type of cataract (opacification of the lens) that forms during the course of aging
A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the nucleus of the lens
A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the cortex of the lens
A type of age-related cataract consisting of granular opacities occurring mainly in the central posterior cortex just under the posterior capsule
A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed
A dialeptic seizure is a type of seizure characterised predominantly by reduced responsiveness or awareness and with subsequent at least partial amnesia of the event

A typical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by its sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would usually show 3 Hz generalized epileptiform discharges during the event

concept.display: obsolete Absence seizures with special features

concept.definition: An absence with eyelid myoclonia seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by forced upward jerking of the eyelids during an absence seizure

Myoclonic absence seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by an interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare and rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with 3 Hz generalized spike-wave discharges on the electroencephalogram. Duration is typically 10-60 s. Whilst impairment of consciousness may not be obvious the ILAE classified this seizure as a generalized non-motor seizure in 2017
Atypical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged atypical absence seizure
Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years
A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by a motor sign as its initial semiological manifestation
An autonomic seizure is a type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by alteration of autonomic nervous system function as the initial semiological feature

concept.display: obsolete Focal autonomic seizures with altered responsiveness
obsolete Focal autonomic seizures without altered responsiveness

concept.definition: A focal sensory seizure is a type seizure beginning with a subjective sensation

concept.display: Focal sensory seizure with auditory features
concept.definition: A seizure characterized by elementary auditory phenomena including buzzing, ringing, drumming or single tones as its first clinical manifestation

concept.display: Focal autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena
concept.definition: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by symptoms or signs pertaining to the gastrointestinal system as the initial semiological feature

concept.display: Focal sensory seizure with gustatory features
concept.definition: A seizure characterized by taste phenomena including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic tastes as its first clinical manifestation

concept.display: Focal sensory seizure with olfactory features
concept.definition: Seizures characterized by olfactory phenomena as its first clinical manifestation
Auras with affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events

concept.display: Focal sensory seizure with somatosensory features
concept.definition: A seizure characterized by sensory phenomena including tingling, numbness, electric-shock like sensation, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move as its first clinical manifestation
A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions

concept.display: Focal sensory seizure with visual features
concept.definition: A seizure characterized by elementary visual hallucinations such as flashing or flickering lights/colours, or other shapes, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis as its first clinical manifestation

A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus
A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained increase in muscle contraction, lasting a few seconds to minutes
Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures

Generalized clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by sustained bilateral jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups
A generalized myoclonic-atonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterized by a myoclonic jerk followed by an atonic motor component

A short generalized seizure, of a duration of <15 min, not recurring within 24 h, occurring during a febrile episode not caused by an acute disease of the nervous system intracranial infection or severe metabolic disturbance

A febrile seizure that has any of the following features: focal semiology (or associated with post-ictal neurologic abnormalities beyond drowsiness, such as a Todd's paresis), prolonged seizure beyond 15 minutes, or recurring (occurring more than once) in a 24 hour period
A type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by an arrest or pause of activities, freezing, or immobilization as the predominant semiological feature throughout the seizure

A focal seizure characterized at onset by predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements
A type of focal motor seizure characterised by sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline as the initial semiological manifestation
An EEG with constitutional variants contains waves that are rare or unusual but not generally pathologic
EEG background activity at 4-5/second
EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz)
EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz)
EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz)
EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz)

Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure

concept.display: EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges
concept.definition: Focal epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

concept.display: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
concept.definition: Generalized epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)
EEG discharges recorded in particular areas of a localized (focal) abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG)

concept.display: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere
concept.definition: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to contralateral hemisphere but without secondary generalization

concept.display: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere
concept.definition: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to the hemisphere on the same side of the brain

concept.display: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
concept.definition: Focal EEG discharges that secondarily spread to both hemispheres and can then be recorded over the entire scalp
Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in both hemispheres

concept.display: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
concept.definition: Epileptiform discharges identified at multiple locations temporarily in both hemispheres and temporarily in one hemisphere
Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in one hemisphere
Focal epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec

concept.display: EEG with series of focal spikes
concept.definition: Focal spikes occurring for several seconds

concept.display: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave
EEG discharges recorded on the entire scalp typically seen in persons with epilepsy

concept.display: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave

concept.display: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
concept.definition: Generalized epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies
EEG with abnormal amplitude
EEG frequency is abnormally increased
EEG with abnormally slow frequencies
EEG showing diffuse slowing without interruption
Non-continuous diffuse slowing of electroencephalographic patterns

concept.display: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
concept.definition: Slowing at frequencies between 7.5 and 8.5 Hz

concept.display: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
concept.definition: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 4-7 Hz

concept.display: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
concept.definition: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 0.5-3 Hz

concept.display: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
concept.definition: EEG without electrical activity
Slowing in occipital areas of the scalp EEG

concept.display: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade I
concept.definition: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital regions during photic stimulation

concept.display: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade II
concept.definition: Occurence of epileptiform discharges in occipital and central regions during photic stimulation

concept.display: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade III
concept.definition: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital, central, temporal and parietal regions during photic stimulation

concept.display: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade IV
concept.definition: Occurrence of generalized epileptiform discharges during photic stimulation
Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere
An abnormal shape of occiput

concept.display: Abnormal shape of the frontal region
concept.definition: An abnormal shape of the frontal part of the head
Facial height (length) is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparent decrease in the height (length) of the face (subjective)
Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone
Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest
Posterior positioning of the glabella, i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges
Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella
Absent eyelids
Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva
Absence or underdevelopment of the eyelid
An abnormal elevation of the C-reactive protein level in serum
An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve
Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow
An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location
Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly
Elevated ridge(s) of skin starting well below the medial aspect of the lower lid that curves gradually upward toward and/or across the nasal bridge
Antihelix protrusion directed more anteriorly than laterally, forming a shelf overlying the posterior concha
No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix
Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix
Antihelical ridge that forms an acute angle between the antitragus and its bifurcation (stem) instead of a gently curving arc
Increased width of the inferred cross-section of the inferior crus
Increased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem
Decreased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem
Increased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of the helix
Posterior curving of the antihelix from its origin at the antitragus, traveling initially almost perpendicular to the descending helix and obscuring some of the concha
Decreased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of a normal helix

concept.display: Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix
concept.definition: An abnormality of the inferior crus of the antihelix is the lower cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa
An abnormality of the stem of the antihelix, which is the part below the bifurcation of the antihelix into the inferior and superior crura

concept.display: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
concept.definition: An abnormality of the superior crus of the antihelix is the upper cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa
Decreased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem
Increased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem
Positioning of the antitragus at an angle perpendicular to the plane of the ear (oriented away from the plane of the ear)
Absence of the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix
Double rather than single peak of the antitragus
Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix
Invagination of the superior part of the auricle under a fold of temporal skin
A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and superior crus
A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and inferior crus that are affected
Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha

concept.display: Crus of helix connected to antihelix
concept.definition: Extension of the ridge of the crus helix across the ear and connection of the crus to the antihelix
Curving course of the crus of the helix, approaching or joining the antitragus

concept.display: Tragal bridge of crus of helix
concept.definition: The anterior origin of the crus encompasses the superior margin of the tragus, the crus overrides the upper portion of the conchal cavum and ends at the antihelix

concept.display: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix
concept.definition: Widening, rather than tapering, of the crus at its posterior border near the antihelix
Small defect of the helical fold that lies at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix
Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix
Linear, circumferential indentation in the convexity of the outer surface of the helix
Positioning of the anterior surface of the ear lobe in a more coronal plane than the remainder of the ear
Interruption between the ascending helix and the crus helix, allowing the ascending helix to be attached directly to the mastoid
Discontinuity in the convexity of the inferior margin of the lobe
Presence of all the normal ear components and the median longitudinal length more than two standard deviations below the mean
Presence of some auricular structures, but none of these structures conform to recognized ear components
Lack of convexity or prominence of the contour of the ridge between the bottom of the incisura and the confluence of the ascending helix and crus helix
Increased height of the tragal ridge with a shallow indentation at the apex, giving the appearance of a double peak
A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus
Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus
Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus
Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes
Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection
Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial avium complex infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection

concept.display: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology

concept.definition: A type of pulmonary sequestration that occurs within the visceral pleura of normal lung tissue, usually without communication with the tracheobronchial tree
An abnormality of the concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine
An abnormality of calcium concentration in the urine
An abnormal level of urinary catecholamine concentration
An abnormality of the hindbrain, also known as the rhombencephalon
An abnormality of the metencephalon. The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment does not extend beyond the upper sigmoid
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment extends proximal to the sigmoid
A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment comprises the entire colon

concept.display: EEG with occipital sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the occipital region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave

concept.display: EEG with parietal sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the parietal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave

concept.display: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the temporal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave

concept.display: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the frontal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave

concept.display: EEG with central sharp slow waves
concept.definition: EEG with sharp slow waves in the central region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave
EEG with sharp waves in the occipital region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
EEG with sharp waves in the frontal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
EEG with sharp waves in the parietal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
EEG with sharp waves in the temporal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec
A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe
A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a finger
Increased width of the distal segment of a finger
The total absence of the foot, with no bony elements distal to the tibia or fibula
For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length
The contour of the foot in lateral profile has a convex shape
Increased thumb width without increased dorso-ventral dimension
The absence of a phalangeal segment of a toe or hallux
Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole)
Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual
The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal
A crease that connects the proximal and distal transverse palmar creases
Extension of the proximal transverse crease (five finger crease) to the ulnar edge of the palm
A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature
Decreased width of nail
An abnormality of size or shape of the long bones
Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures
Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture
Unicoronal synostosis affecting only the right coronal suture
Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture
Premature synostosis of both lambdoid sutures
Premature synostosis of only one lambdoid suture
Premature synostosis of only the left lambdoid suture
Premature synostosis of only the right lambdoid suture
Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin
Craniosynostosis involving at least 2 cranial sutures, where the exact pattern of sutures fused has not been precisely specified
Craniosynostosis of all calvarial sutures
Asymmetry of the anterior part of the skull
Asymmetry of the posterior part of the skull
An abnormality of the fontanelle
Any anomaly of a cranial suture, that is one of the six membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant
Premature fusion of the metopic suture
Unilateral atrophy of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin
Unilateral underdevelopment of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones
Asymmetry observed in the face of a neonate or infant whose face appears symmetric at rest and asymmetric during crying as the mouth is pulled downward on one side while not moving on the other side
Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead
Bilateral temporal scarlike defects, which are said to resemble forceps marks
An abnormality of the outline, configuration, or contour of the mouth
An abnormality of the vermilion border, the sharp demarcation between the lip (red colored) and the adjacent normal skin

concept.display: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
concept.definition: A subtle unilateral cleft of the upper lip, which may appear as a small indentation
Increased width of the upper lip
A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child
A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child
A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child
A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts
A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts
An abnormality involving the movement of the eye outwards

concept.display: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
concept.definition: An abnormality of the abducens nerve
Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward
A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others
A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others
A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others
Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries
An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region
A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized
An abnormality of the skin that is restricted to a particular body region
Reduced pigmentation of hair diffusely
Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair
An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth that is acquired during the course of life
A congenital abnormality of the distribution of hair growth
An abnormal amount of hair
Hair whose growth rate deviates from the norm
Hypopigmented hair that appears white
Reduced pigmentation of hair in patches
Yellowish discoloration of the nails
Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin
Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area
Increased susceptibility to cutaneous fungal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of cutaneous fungal infections
Increased susceptibility to viral skin infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral skin infections
Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect

Incomplete formation of the cochlear partition. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani separated by the cochlear partition, except in the apical turn where the two scalae are in continuity via the helicotrema

concept.display: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
concept.definition: Incomplete partition I is also known as cystic cochleovestibular malformation, where the cochlea has no bony modiolus, resulting in an empty cystic cochlea. This is accompanied by a dilated cystic vestibule with developmental arrest at the fifth week of gestation
Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect

concept.display: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
concept.definition: A morphological abnormality of the vestibule, the central part of the osseous labyrinth that is situated medial to the tympanic cavity, behind the cochlea, and in front of the semicircular canals
Complete absence of the vestibule of the inner ear

concept.display: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
concept.definition: Underdevelopment of the vestibule of the inner ear

concept.display: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
concept.definition: Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear

concept.display: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
concept.definition: An abnormality of the morphology of the semicircular canal
Absence of the semicircular canal
Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal
Increased size of the semicircular canal

concept.display: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
concept.definition: An abnormality of the Internal acoustic meatus, i.e., of the canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone through which the cranial nerve VII and cranial nerve VIII traverse
Aplasia of the internal auditory canal
Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal
Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct
Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular

concept.display: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
concept.definition: An abnormality of the function of the inner ear

concept.display: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear
concept.definition: A structural anomaly of the internal part of the ear

concept.display: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear

concept.definition: Absence of the vestibular nerv
Underdevelopment of the vestibular nerve
Absence or underdevelopment of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect

concept.display: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
concept.definition: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus
Reduced muscle tone secondary to an abnormality of the central nervous system
Atrophy of the tibialis muscle
An abnormality of myelination of nerves in the central nervous system
Delayed myelination in the peripheral nervous system
Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs that is lethal at birth
A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in infancy
Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 3 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 4 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age
Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy)
Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately
Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex
